To solve this question, we need to understand the concept of forces and their effect on motion. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction that the object is moving, it causes the object's speed to decrease. 

Options (A) and (C) are not relevant to the question as they describe unrelated scenarios. Option (B) states that a car is being pushed in the same direction that it is moving, so it would not cause the object's speed to decrease. 

Option (D) is the correct answer because it describes a situation where a car is driving north but strong winds are blowing south. The strong winds acting against the direction of motion of the car would create a force that acts in the opposite direction to the object's motion, causing its speed to decrease.

This question requires an understanding of forces and their effects on an object's motion. When a force acts on an object in the opposite direction to its motion, it causes the object to slow down or decrease in speed. In option (D), the car is moving in a northern direction, but the strong winds are blowing in the opposite direction, which is southward. This opposing force of the wind acts against the car's forward motion and causes it to slow down. Option (A) is incorrect because the movement of bees flying north and a car driving west are unrelated to each other. Option (B) is incorrect because the person pushing the car in the same direction as its motion would actually increase its speed, not decrease it. Option (C) is incorrect because the rising sun is not a force acting against the car's motion, but rather a natural occurrence.

This question requires a basic understanding of the relationship between forces and motion. According to Newton's second law of motion, an object will accelerate or decelerate based on the net force acting upon it. The net force is the vector sum of all the forces acting on the object. In this case, the force acting on the car in the opposite direction that the car is moving is the strong winds blowing south. This force acts against the car's forward motion, causing its speed to decrease. Option (A) is incorrect because the bees flying north and the car driving west are not directly influencing each other's motion. Option (B) is incorrect because the person is pushing the car in the same direction it is already moving, so there is no force acting in the opposite direction. Option (C) is incorrect because the rising sun does not directly influence the car's motion.

This question requires an understanding of Newton's laws of motion and the concept of forces. According to Newton's first law of motion, an object will continue moving in the same direction with the same speed unless acted upon by an external force. So, in order for the object's speed to decrease in a forward motion, there needs to be a force acting on the object in the opposite direction.

Option (D) is the correct answer because the strong winds blowing south create a force that opposes the forward motion of the car driving north. This force acts in the opposite direction of the car's motion, causing its speed to decrease.

Option (A) is incorrect because the motion of the bees flying north and the car driving west are not directly related.

Option (B) is incorrect because the person pushing the car in the same direction that it is already moving does not create a force in the opposite direction.

Option (C) is incorrect because the rising of the sun in the east does not create a force opposing the car's motion.

Option (A) is unrelated because it describes two different objects moving in different directions. Option (B) is incorrect because the force and the motion are in the same direction. In this case, the force acting on the car in the opposite direction that it is moving is the strong winds blowing south.
